html:
The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist. The opinions expressed are his own.

By Robert Cyran

NEW YORK, Jan 27 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Apple AAPL.O boss Tim Cook would prefer not to have supply-chain challenges. Yet it's becoming one of the better kinds of problem to have. Technology investors are worried the pandemic brought forward years of future revenue, especially for cloud-based companies, and that growth will now slow. The $2.6 trillion Apple instead may be poised for a rebound as it satiates pent-up demand for iPhones.

It's early, but 2022 has been a rough year for tech investors. Apple’s stock is down about 10%. Peers Amazon.com AMZN.O, Microsoft MSFT.O and Facebook owner Meta Platforms FB.O have done worse. And Apple has performed far better than highly valued upstarts, such as e-commerce outfit Shopify SHOP.TO, which has lost a third of its market capitalization in less than a month.

Apple shares trade at 27 times estimated earnings over the next 12 months, using Refinitiv data. That’s higher (Full Story) than its recent average, but still lower than its giant tech peers. And it is far lower than multiples attached to fast-growing stocks: Shopify still trades at over 100 times estimated earnings. So there’s less froth to be flattened at Apple.

Furthermore, while most internet-based tech firms have seen rapid top-line expansion during the pandemic, it has been more of a mixed bag for Apple. Sure, if people spend more time on phones in lockdown, that is good for the company’s services business, which accounted for 22% of its total revenue of $83 billion in the quarter to September. But iPhone sales brought in over twice as much revenue that quarter. The company estimates silicon shortages and manufacturing disruptions reduced revenue by $6 billion in the period.

As the pandemic recedes, tech firms that have capitalized on virtual living should indeed see growth rates slow. In contrast, time will iron out Apple’s supply-chain difficulties, as chip production expands and factory employees get back to work.

Cook will have new numbers for the last calendar quarter of 2021 to talk about on Thursday after market’s close. Perhaps impatient customers might switch to a different phone, but Apple’s users tend to be hard to dislodge. Apple had a 15% share of the global smartphone market last quarter according to researcher IDC, up from 12.5% five years ago. Besides, other handset makers have chip troubles too. The missing iPhone sales are probably just delayed.

Follow @rob_cyran on Twitter


CONTEXT NEWS

- Apple is set to report earnings for its second fiscal quarter to December on Jan. 27 after U.S. markets close.

- On Oct. 28, Chief Executive Tim Cook said in a call with investors that supply constraints reduced revenue by about $6 billion in the quarter ending Sept. 25. He blamed industry-wide silicon shortages and Covid-19 manufacturing disruption.


(Editing by Richard Beales and Sharon Lam)

((For previous columns by the author, Reuters customers can click on CYRAN/
